Q2
```{r}
hist(burd[,'WIWR'], breaks = 0:8 -.5)
mean(burd[,'WIWR'])


sum(log(dpois(x = burd[,'WIWR'], lambda = 1.46)))
```

Q3
```{r}
n <- as.numeric(sum(table(burd$WIWR)))
probability <- mean(sum(burd$WIWR)/n)
```


```{r}
k <- seq(.01, .99, by = 0.01)
y <- NULL

List = list()

for (i in k){

sum<- sum(log(dbinom(burd$WIWR, 6, prob = i)))
temp <- data.frame(i, sum)
y <- rbind(y, temp)
}

plot(x = y$i, y = y$sum, xlab = "p", ylab = "log likelihood")


```

Q4
The Binomial distribution has a higher log likelihood than the Poisson distribution
Poisson distribution is more appropriate for census count data.
